Brennen Green

I am a computer science student interested in the domain of computer graphics. I am inspired by the intersection of art and technology, specifically for the domain of film and games. I am particularly interested in the topics of rendering, animation, technical art, and game engines. I seek to continue building solution which enable artists to produce the artistic vision without having to worry about the limitation of the technology given to them. I've fulfill this interest so far in multiple ways: through my experience at Twitch where I had ownership of a brand new tool which allowed for the rendering of dynamic stream content on streams. And, coming in the summer of 2022, I'll be working at Blizzard Entertainment on World of Warcraft's Game Engine team, helping develop next generation 3D Graphics Systems.

My passion is for enabling the development of inspiring and entertaining works of arts. Assiting artists by providing the necesssary tooling, technology, and pipelines to fulfill their artistic vision in the most frictionless environment possible.

When I'm not obsessing over computer graphics however, you can find me playing games, cooking, skating, surfing or doing anything outdoors!

Experience

Software Development / Computer Graphics

As a software developer, I've taken a passionate interest in the design and optimization of low-level systems and tools. Specifically, I have professionally backed experience in developing tooling and systems meant to enable the use and validation of complex low level systems. This experience started at Intel where I worked as a validation engineer, designing automated test cases for pre-silicon CPU designs. I expanded into the domain of Computer Graphics in pursuit of my passion for enabling artists and their artistic vision. Since then, I had the amazing opportunity to work as a Android Graphics Engineer at Twitch, owning a novel rendering system developed with OpenGL ES to render dynamic streaming visuals for our mobile-only creators. On my next quest however, I will be joining Blizzard Entertainment working as a Graphics Programmer on the World of Warcraft team, helping to develop a new generation suite of tools aimed at enabling artists to their fullest capacity to create captivating, inspirational, and entertaining worlds for the game.

  • LinkedIn
  • Resume

Research

My academic research falls into primarily two areas: Computer Graphics and Machine Learning. As a undergraduate research assistant at UK I worked in both imaging and machine learning. While working in a biomedical imaging lab I developed an optimized biomedical imaging device that would allow the reconstruction of cerebral bloodflow using CUDA and MATLAB. Currently I am researching the applications of convolutional neural networks to characterize part defects and optimize manufacturing processes with the Institute of Sustainable Manufacturing at UK. The bulk of my work involves heavy amounts of data analysis and processing using Python and tools such as Tensorflow, Keras, Pytorch, CUDA, and Pandas to enable my machine learning workflow.

Personal Projects

Personally, my work is focused entirely on computer graphics. Typically I am working on some sort of rendering engine, both physically based and real-time. I have written several rendering algorithms from scratch for my own developmental purposes as well. My goal at the moment is to maintain two fully functional engines. One for real-time optimization work and another for photorealistic work. In development with these engines I typically work with Modern C++, OpenGL, and Vulkan. Outside of that I try to remain constantly involved with the open-source community; in the past I have contributed to both Blender and Godot Engine.
